# Major Scale in F (Mode: Phrygian, Shape: C)

The F Major scale is a diatonic scale comprised of the following notes: F, G, A, Bb, C, D, and E. The Phrygian mode, when applied to the F major scale, creates a dark and exotic feel due to the lowered second note, G, and the lowered sixth note, D.

## Notes and Intervals:

- F (root)
- G (minor 2nd)
- A (minor 3rd)
- Bb (perfect 4th)
- C (perfect 5th)
- D (minor 6th)
- E (minor 7th)

## Genre and Musical Flavor:

The F Major scale in the Phrygian mode is often used in genres that require a mysterious or exotic sound. This scale creates tension and has a unique quality that can add depth and complexity to compositions in metal, flamenco, and various forms of world music. The lowered second and sixth notes contribute to the distinct and somewhat unsettling feel of this scale.
